newsitem.title: USA: Missing truck, training missiles found in Texas.
newsitem.headline: Missing truck, training missiles found in Texas.

text.p: A missing truck loaded with four training missiles was found in West Texas Friday and its driver was taken into custody by the FBI, the Air Force said.
The missiles, which were not equipped with explosive warheads, were found behind a supply store in Ranger, Texas, west of Dallas, Air Force spokesman Lou Timmons said.
"The truck was found at a place called Ranger Supply. We believe the crates containing the missiles are still in place and intact," he said.

The driver, Ronald Dean Coy, was arrested at the Flying J truck stop near Beaumont, east of Houston. Coy faces charges of theft of government property and theft of an interstate shipment and was taken to Atlanta for processing, he said.

The TGM-130 missiles, mock-ups of AGM-130 air-to-ground missiles, were being shipped from Duluth, Ga., to Cannon Air Force Base near Clovus, N.M., for use in Roving Sands '97, a joint tactical air operation that includes about 20,000 troops from the United States, Germany, Canada and The Netherlands.
Mounted on F-15 warplanes, the missiles could seek out targets but could not be fired. "The four missiles never were a threat to anybody," Timmons said.
The missile shipment had been scheduled to arrive at Cannon AFB April 21, four days after Coy called base officials and said he had been delayed by mechanical problems.
The truck was one of two military shipments reported missing this week. Officials found a truck carrying mortars and machineguns for the military late Thursday.
